description.plain: Marvin Bernard (born March 31, 1978), better known by his stage name Tony Yayo, is an American rapper, hype man, and member of the hip hop group G-Unit. Tony Yayo was brought up in South Jamaica, Queens, New York and his longtime friends with 50 Cent and Lloyd Banks. He is signed to 50 Cent’s record label G-Unit Records and recently signed a deal with EMI to release his second untitled album. He is CEO to the label G-Unit Philly. His stage name is derived from the 1983 film Scarface, referencing the character Tony Montana and the slang word for cocaine.

songs.full_title: I Know You Don't Love Me by Tony Yayo (Ft. G-Unit)
songs.title: I Know You Don’t Love Me
songs.title_with_featured: I Know You Don't Love Me (Ft. G-Unit)

description.plain: G-Unit member 50 Cent sings the chorus while Tony Yayo and G-Unit members Young Buck and Lloyd Banks rap on their own verses. The song tells the story of how the rappers are engaging in a relationship with the same woman, though she does not know they know, and how they know she does not love any of them because her obvious flirtatiousness and love for other rappers. Several other rappers and performers are mentioned in the song along with examples of what she does that proves she does not truly love any of her men, as evidenced by the chorus (“I know you don’t love me, you ain’t the same when Jay-Z’s around / I know you don’t love me / I know you don’t love me, you scream and holla when Eminem’s in town.).

songs.full_title: Drama Setter by Tony Yayo (Ft. Eminem & Obie Trice)
songs.title: Drama Setter

description.plain: “Drama Setter” was released on Tony Yayo’s debut album, Thoughts of a Predicate Felon. The album was released in 2005 and sold 214,000 in its first week. Production for the song was handled by Eminem, Luis Resto, and Jeff Bass. “Drama Setter” was not released as a single for the album.

songs.full_title: Curious by Tony Yayo (Ft. Joe)
songs.title: Curious

description.plain:
“Curious” is the second single released off Tony Yayo’s debut album, Thoughts of a Predicate Felon. The single features R&B artist Joe on the chorus of the song.



For the chart issue dated September 10, 2005, “Curious” debuted at number 94 on the US Billboard Hot R&B/Hip-Hop Songs chart: it went on to peak at number 85, spending five weeks on the chart in total. Chart-position wise, “Curious” became the second most successful single from Thoughts of a Predicate Felon, behind only the album’s first single, “So Seductive”, which reached number seven on the corresponding chart and also peaked at number 48 on the US Billboard Hot 100.

songs.full_title: Tattle Teller by Tony Yayo
songs.title: Tattle Teller

description.plain:
This song is written about snitches but mostly aimed at Fat Joe, the terror squad rapper from New York. G-Unit had beef with Fat Joe around the time “The Massacre” came out.

Before releasing The Massacre, Jackson recorded a song “Piggy Bank”, a response to Ja Rule’s song “New York”, which was leaked before the album’s release. The song takes aim at rappers including Fat Joe, Nas, and Jadakiss.[8] Fat Joe responded with a song, “My Fofo”, accusing Jackson of taking steroids, hiding in his home, and being jealous of The Game. Jadakiss also responded with a song, “Checkmate”, and said that Jackson was trying to “create a buzz for his new album”.[9] The “Piggy Bank” music video portrays animated caricatures of Jadakiss (as a Ninja turtle), Fat Joe (as King Hippo from Mike Tyson’s Punch-Out), Nas (as a kid chasing a “milkshake” truck in a Superman costume), and The Game (as Mr. Potato Head). He also disses all of them on the beef version of his single “Window Shopper”[10] Kelis, Nas' then-wife, responded to the song on her single “Bossy”.[citation needed] Nas later responded with “Don’t Body Ya Self (MC Burial).” Nas later dissed 50 on the song “Street Ridaz” on Game’s mixtape “Brake Lights”.
(from wikipedia)

songs.title: Haters
songs.title_with_featured: Haters (Ft. 50 Cent, Roscoe Dash & Shawty Lo)

description.plain:
“Haters” is the second single from Tony Yayo’s unreleased second studio album. The song features fellow rapper 50 Cent, Roscoe Dash and deceased Shawty Lo. The song was released as a digital download on March 23, 2011.

The video was shot at Mansion Elan, a club in Atlanta. Rapper Kidd Kidd replaces Roscoe Dash in the video. DJ Drama makes a cameo appearance.

The single charted on the U.S. Billboard Hot R&B/Hip-Hop Songs and this saw Tony Yayo’s first song on the chart since 2005.

songs.title: Pass the Patron

description.plain:
The first single from Tony Yayo’s yet-to-be-released second studio album.

The song features fellow rapper 50 Cent and was produced by Punch.

The song was released as a digital download on May 20, 2010.



Unsurprisingly, you’ll be hard-pressed trying to find these lyrics anywhere else on the Internet. This may be why.

description.plain:
A freestyle-esque single released on April 13th, 2015.



The instrumental is from Black Moon’s track Reality.



This track is apart of a current 90’s themed trend which the G-Unit members are taking part of. Rap affiliate and fellow G-Unit member Lloyd Banks released a freestyle cover over Black Moon’s track, How Many MC’s.
